description.text:
This is a derivative of both thing:1088 and thing:1082, with inspiration from the improved snap from thing:5322.  However the pattern was totally redrawn from basic principles to make it fully parametric, rather than relying on the original dxf outlines.
The point of this design is to take full advantages of the abilities of a 3d printer, rather than just converting a laser cut design into a 3d part with difficult overhangs.  The triangle should end up fully trapped inside the case.
Note that from a top view, it may appear the triangle and case overlap, but from a per-layer perspective, they are separated by the tolerance, and do not actually touch.

Due to the large square area, this part may warp without a heated build platform. The second verison is identical to the first, except that I have added ears that seem to help significantly (with my sample population of one) to prevent warping. (Thanks for the idea: http://blog.makerbot.com/2011/02/25/mouse-ears-defeat-corner-curling-monster/ ) The parts should come out separated, but may be initially connected by raft and strings. Carefully cut these away so the triangle rolls smoothly in the case. Since all interior faces are 45 degree angles, it should be easy to slip a knife between the parts to do any necessary cleaning. Note that skeinforge 35 and previous do not slice this object correctly (although build quality suffers only slightly). This was fixed somewhere between skeinforge 35 and 40.

This builds on the thingiverse car mount by wdawes ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207977 ). I added the pieces here, allowing for you to convert that car mount into a desk stand. [go to the link for the vertical mount, I have the horizontal version of the mount] -
for iPhone4 in otterbox commuter case (sized for case)

How to set up the parts is pretty self-explanatory from the pictures. There is some give in the parts, the looseness can be remedied by a shim (of paper of support plastic from a 3D print), or glue (if you don't care to disassemble it)... or you can try resizing the parts.It can hold the phone at different angles (for the phone to balance horizontal/parallel to the desk you have to rotate the base 180 degrees). The angle mechanism may become loose (but you can print multiples and glue them to your desired angles, and switch them out).
I made it from wdawes' car mount ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207977 ). I also updated his design for horizontal viewing (present in my files. I did not re-post his original design, but his design fits on my apparatus if desired.
The pictures I present use wdawes' version of the car mount (phone holder).

Ok - my take on the cupcake end stop, after trashing the kapton belt for the second time on the automated build platform v1 (ABP). This is due to Z axis skipping so until I can resolve the skipping the importance of a Z stop is critical.
I had a spare microswitch and 10k resistor so came up with this, hope it save's other peoples belts.
P.S. I found it really fiddly to set up but have not needed to adjust once done.

Print out one of ZstopA and one ZstopB The B print will be a bit lumpy but main thing with it is that it fits inside A, will slide within and does not stick out, a bit of sand paper sorted mine out. Get your old ethernet cable, cut of one end to the length of cable you need (my cable was actually one I found in my bits box, it actually only had 4 cores to pins 5,6,7 & 8, for this you only need pins 5,6 & 7). Solder the core that goes to pin 5 of ethernet plug (+5v) to one end of the resister
Solder the core that goes to pin 6 of ethernet plug (Signal) to the other end of the resister but leave long tail. (See picture)
Insulate with tape or heat shrink.
Solder the long tail to common on the switch (use long tail to pull through the eye of the switch lug, you should solder very close to resister and cut of the remaining tail).
Solder the core that goes to pin 7 of the ethernet plug (Ground) to the N/O contact of the switch.
(normally open so that when the switch is pressed it grounds the signal line the 10K ohm resister prevents excessive current from the 5V line).
Cut back all other cores, maker sure no shorts on any cores connected to pins 4 and 8 as these will have +5v and Ground respectively. Assemble together, although during the above I constantly made sure the lead lenghts were good (hope you do as it was fiddly even then). Set the set screw so you can adjust switch height both in and out. Set up your print head to the height you want, move X/Y axis out the way, place switch where you want it with the switch made and mark the holes. You may need to remove the Z axis plate, I just wound it to the top, drill the holes and fit switch. MAJOR NOTE MAKE SURE YOU DONT DRILL INTO YOUR ELECTRONICS, notice on my machine the switch is placed between the electronics boards mounting holes. I did not pre check mine I just plugged it into the Z axis stepper drive top plug and ran the motor with control panel, initially I used my finger to press the switch to make sure it worked then dropped to correct level and adjusted with allen key.

title: Bath Tub Stopper with pull handle

description.text: Due to mine not working any more, and not finding one I liked here. I came up with this simple print. No support needed. Print with the handle portion flat on the bed. I added rubber around the inner part and pushed it flush with the outer ring. I cut it from an old bicycle tube. Other ideas you could use maybe: rubber cement may work a little, you could cut some wax paper and out it down in the tub and shoot some hot glue on the part and push it down. It would stick to the wax paper so you could remove the paper after it cools and it should be a decent seal, If you have gasket material or silicone you could do the same.

title: Electric Parametric Violin (EPV) Revision 2 CAD Files

description.text: This Thing contains the Solidworks CAD files used to build all the EPV.  If you wish to modify the EPV design, you have come to the right place.  If you wish to build an EPV, then you should consult the list of links below.

If you wish to build an EPV, use the links below to select the size you wish to build.
4/4 Scale
3/4 Scale
1/2 Scale
1/4 Scale
1/8 Scale
1/16 Scale

The EPV is based on David Perry's excellent F-F-Fiddle, which you can find right here. My daughter has been taking violin lessons recently, and I wanted to build an electric violin. While the F-F-Fiddle is really nice, I was not able to easily scale it down for a 6 year old girl - so used it as inspiration and then designed and build 1/2 scale violin for her. As soon as that was finished, my son (age three) decided that he needed one too, so I refined the design and built a [1/16 scale violin].(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:457018) for him. At this point, I thought I was finished, but then the violin teacher was extremely excited and asked her if I could make her one too. At this point, I threw up my hands, said "Why not?" and decided that my next design was going to be scalable so that I could make any size violin that someone would ask for. And now, you can too!

It's an icosahedron! I made this for a friend of mine, and I thought I might as well share. I don't think there's an icosahedron that's hollow already up here.
I'll upload my source file too. This was a fun object to model, because it can be constructed with three perpendicular golden rectangles.

I sliced mine at 50% scale, and with 0.4 mm layers the walls ended up being 3 extrusions thick, which was just about right. Of course, the top will need to be bridged, so make sure you've got your temperature and feed rate settings calibrated or it may droop!

comments.text: Your model was one of the first things I printed when I got my 3D printer, several years ago. I printed it in translucent blue filament, and it's beautiful. When I do my workshops on 3D Printing for Teaching and Learning, I always pass around your model. It is striking and immediately grabs audience attention. It's also a great example of fill because they can see the fill pattern inside the hollow object. Your model quickly connects with math instructors too, and they definitely see the value of 3D-printed objects in their classrooms after they see your Icosahedron. Thanks for making it available on the Thingiverse.

This is a simple mechanical model of a photoelectric rotary encoder, just in case someone else needs to model a bracket to hold it as I am.  This one uses 3x M3 screws for mounting 120 degrees apart. There are two sets of three holes; one set at 14 mm and one set at 15 mm radius from center. The features are accurate to the particular item I received. I don't know how standard this one is, but I have seen several nearly-identical photos like it on ebay listing various resolutions like 360, 400, 600 pulses per revolution. This particular one is ebay item 161297002173.

Edit Nov.15: threaded depth of M3 mounting holes is 6.2 mm
Edit Nov. 24: add "Encoder_Bracket2" with enlarged holes for use with two similar but slightly different encoder geometries

description.text: 2.5d relief

For those Poly-V belts on cars that are set up without tensioning pulleys.  Looks roughly like various designs made out of alloy, beats trying to do it with a screwdriver.   
Scale in the X-axis to get close to the radius of your pulley, pop the stretcher under the belt (and on top of the pulley) and carefully rotate the engine to slip the belt on.  
The height of this object relates to a 5-groove poly-V belt - it is twice the size of the 17mm belt.  
(And a curse upon the engineer who thought it was a good idea to have a belt with no tensioner!)
I made mine with no infill and with ABS, there's quite a lot of force on it.

The Hobbyking FPV250 plastic frame isn't the greatest for mounting the flight controller on and maintaining clean wiring.
This bracket mounts with the normal hole spacing, allows for the flight controller (NanoWii in my case) to mount to the top, and for speed controller wiring, receiver and bluetooth module to be hidden underneath.
It all fits under the main protection bracket piece. I used double sided tape to mount the NanoWii to the bracket.

Printed at 0.14mm layer heights, 35mm/sec on a Prussia i3.
Some minor support structure might be needed under the main platform to help it hold up. I didn't need to because my printer can bridge reasonably well without help. Use double sided tape to mount the flight controller, and you can drill out the frame holes for M3 sized screws/bolts.

I have been on the 3d printing bandwagon for about 6 months now. It's been a wild ride and it's about to get wilder.  I have come across a few articles about 3d printed fabrics and FDM high fashion but none of them seem to share files.   This places 3d printed fashion out of reach.
Until now. (Imagine that in the voice of the guy who announces for the movies)

Announcing the first Wearable 3d Print contest.
The contest runs till the end of February.
The winner will get;
50$ from Linkreincarnate(Money Order)
50$ from Makerbot. (Yay Zach!)
50$ from trebuchet03 (in the PP3DP forums)
That's 150$ guys! Very nice! Not to mention whatever else gets donated to the prize pool. If we have enough people donate to the pool we may add a second and third place prizes depending on what the people who donate want. People who donate to the prize pool can vote for a winner (or waive that vote for the right to enter the contest yourself). I would rather people donated money but gift cards or actual stuff is fine too. To ensure no one calls foul the people who donate will be responsible for shipping the prize that they donated themselves. I will never have any prize other than the 50$ money order in my possession. The rules are simple, * Make something wearable. * Post your designs on Thingiverse as a Public Domain license with the word Wearable somewhere in the title. Also tag it with wearable so it's easy to find. * Post your design files. * Only post stuff that works. (Ie you know it prints and the files are tidy.) * Also entries must be wearable by a normal person, gnomes and lolcats need not apply. * Enter as often as you like. * Feel free to enter past works so long as design files are shared and it is Public Domain. Guidelines for winners...(you can still win while ignoring the following...) * The bigger the better. * Bonus points for 3d printable fabric or snap together type designs. * Minimal vitamins (including cut filament because not everyone uses 3mm filament now) * Avoid rings, earrings, and pendants unless it is truly EPIC (There are a lot of them already) * Try to make something you would actually wear in public. (or a runway) Scale mail is nice but you'll never have a girlfriend while choosing to wear it... not to say that scale mail couldn't win depending on who's doing the voting...

This EDF Unit was made 100% in AutoCAD. I have tested this EDF Unit and it works!.
To be honest its probably not super efficient, but it works, and judging by its thrust and the noise it makes, I think this installed on my Bixler 2 would work. The fan is designed for a 2mm shaft, and 2 3mm nuts and 2 3mm grub screws for securing the fan to the motor. The shell/outside is designed for a 23mm inrunner. I used this one: http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__24929__B20_30_22L_FIN_Brushless_Inrunner_Motor_4220kv.html worked great Please download this and print it if you can :)

description.text:
Rotary (Food) Platter. Update Version 2:
  • Added holes.
  • Larger RotaryPlatterTop.
  • Larger RotaryPlatterFoot.

You additionally need:
3x Alu-Tubes dia 10mm, 100 mm long.
1x Screw M3 x 25mm.
1x M3 Nut
1x Washer dia 3mm.
  • Print 1x http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:53451.
  • Print 1x RotaryPlatterBottom.
  • Print 1x RotaryPlatterTop.
  • Print 3x RotaryPlatterFoot.
  • Insert the Alu-Tubes into the RotaryPlatterBottom.
  • Put the Feed over the Alu-Tubes.
  • Insert the GearBearing into the RotaryPlatterBottom.
  • Insert the RotaryPlatterTop into the GearBearing.
  • Fix the Platter either with screws (wood or similar) or with a tape (glass, ceramic etc.).
    • Enjoy your meal! Update Version 2:
    Use the M3 x 25mm Screw, the M3 Nut and the Washer to fix the RotaryPlatterTop with the GearBearing.

title: iDevice Wall Dock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted a little dock to put my phone on that plugs right into the wall, so I don't have a cord dangling over my two dogs' beds to my nightstand, where they could possibly trip on it and send my phone flying.
I whipped this up in sketchup in 5 minutes, printed it out, cleaned it up, and added the cord. The block goes into one part and plugs into the wall, and the connector wraps around and goes into the slot.

Download, skeinforge, and print. It will likely need some cleanup, especially where the connector goes into the slot.
Disconnect the block from the cord. Then insert the block into the big open part. Make sure you don't insert it backwards. It should fit snugly. It can be inserted vertically and horizontally to fit the outlets in your home.
Then insert the iDevice connector into the slot. Make sure you don't insert it backwards. If it doesn't go in, clean up the slot. It should be a snug fit.
Finally, wrap the cord around the block and then plug it in. Pop it into the wall and plug in your iPhone, iPod, or iPad, and enjoy having your device flat against the wall and no cords snaking around.

title: Ipad Mini stand (for Mini 1 to 3, 6 plus and more)

description.text:
Well after years of having a full sized IPAD I have now been using the mini for some time.  In a nutshell the mini's are brilliant.  This stand also doubles for iphone 6+ as well as the iphone 5s.  They all fit really well in this.  I have tried the Ipod touch too.  
This is a mini version of my other stand and still retains the angular device to the stand to help increase the strength.  Works very well.  
This was also a quicker print file as it uses considerably less plastic than some of the other stands.  The holder gap width is 8.5mm printed.  Two versions available.  The "Mobile" is without holes for screws.  The "Stable" version includes screw holes.  The "Mobile" version is shown in the photos.  
UPDATE: I made a number of updates as (1) I wanted a very snug fit version, (2) I wanted a slightly steeper angle and (3) I noticed that some prints of V1 and V2 would result in less fused plastic around the angular device that resulted in weakness if not printed on one side.  I rectified this by printing on one side which was very strong.  But side printing resulted in more supports and wasted plastic.  So I designed a curved version (V3) which, if printed vertically the either left or right side facing down, is now VERY strong.  Trial and error has suggested reinforced curved sides to be much stronger (and with grooves in the base).  Might just be printing on an UP - but that is what I found.  Using the "grain" of the printed produce to achieve vertical slices rather than horizontal slices makes it much stronger if you like (makes sense).  Anyway V3 and V4 (with button space) added.  
.  
"...cause I signed the letter, Eddie Hitler, brackets, I know where you live so don't pisz about.... elves break easy matey boy!".  
Eddie's letter to Father Christmas from Bottom Series 3 Episode 5 'Holy'.
Designed on sketchup and printed on UP3D printer.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Recently shopping for fridges, the biggest frustration I had was with egg storage. I could not find a single fridge where the egg holders did not commit the sins of ugliness and uselessness. As a staple of my kitchen, the egg should not be retained within an ugly generic hunk of plastic but should be celebrated as is the bread tin or the milk jug.
As for uselessness, I've seen fridges which can hold 10 eggs - presumably I am going to eat the rest of the dozen immediately and raw? In fact, even being able to hold a simple 12 eggs is not sufficient for me, as I usually buy my dozen when I have 1-2 of the last pack remaining. No, my egg holder must be able to scale up and down to meet my egg devouring demands.
Hence, the egg-centric egg holder was born. Holding 7 eggs in a single layer (or 4 more in a daring egg-crobatic pyramid arrangement!) the egg holder has a hexagonal arrangement for optimal packing. Grabbing the outer faces of the egg holder and lifting the tray up reveals the second nested egg holder which can be placed on top of the first loaded layer (or next to the first if you have enough fridge space) for a total of 14 eggs (or 18 in a pyramid). When not in use, just nest the holders back together for optimal space utilization.
3D printable and immediately usable straight off the bed, I hope you find this design egg-celent!

comments.text: I don't want to beat up on you, but you don't need a pun eggstravaganza to sell this design. I've found a simple description will prOVOke people to scramble to their printers and whip something up. I'm no spring chicken, so just trust me, your fresh-hatched jokes aren't all they're cracked up to be, and they definitely won't be scoring you any chicks.

title: Replacement Roller for Antique Tape Dispenser

description.text:
This beautiful antique cast iron tape dispenser found in a thrift store was sadly waiting unused in a corner, because it was missing its roller element. Modern-day standard rollers are smaller and therefore did not fit in the slot. 3D printing always has a solution!
Made by Alessandro @ Fab Lab Zurich

Nothing specialâ€¦ The calculated support would have created far too much chaos, though, so I made a customized support made of small pillars. They are very easy to break away after printing and leave a very clean area. During printing of the parallel barrel, you can increase print speed up to 220 % for time convenience. Donâ€™t forget to set down again when you reach the thin part!

title: Spherical panorama tripod head for Sigma 10-20mm lens

description.text:
Update: I added PanCam_PanBaseA_45.stl to the files, this base snaps every 45 degrees instead of 30 degrees, it works better to do panoramas with the camera in portrait position.
Here's a link to a spherical panorama taken with this tripod head: https://ssl.panoramio.com/photo_explorer#view=photo&position=0&with_photo_id=114493851&order=date_desc&user=8522613 Another one: https://ssl.panoramio.com/photo_explorer#view=photo&position=0&with_photo_id=114526388&order=date_desc&user=8522613 This is a tripod head to take spherical panoramas using a Sigma 10-20mm lens.
The head rotates the lens around the focal point, so that there is no perspective distortion; it also has a 30 degree snap rotation mechanism for the panning and a 30 degree increment (from -30 to +45 degrees) ratchet for the tilt to make taking each exposure, well, a snap.
It needs a bunch of M3x20 countersunk screws (plus one 25mm long one for the clamp hinge) a couple M6 bolts for the tilt axis and two M5 bolts for the clamp tightening screw and the base screw.
The latches need a spring, 5mm in diameter and around 2cm in length, I suppose the spring from a pen could work.

I used silicone grease on the panning mechanism to get a more smooth operation. There are a few options for the panning snap angles, PanBaseA is every 30 degrees (12 stops), PanBaseA_45 every 45 (8 stops) and PanBaseA_52 every 52 degrees (5 stops).
For PanBaseA and PanBaseA_45 the symetrical PanBaseB part can be used, PanBaseB_OneSide is for PanBaseA_52 or if you would like to have a less strong snapping action.

comments.text: Awesome work, is it possible to generate a lens ring with 66mm diameter for a walimex / samyang, instead of 73mm?
comments.author: Mikesn

comments.text:
Changing the diameter of the ring is easy, but the distance from the ring to the pivot point probably has to change too. As it is now the mechanism works by pivoting around the focal plane of the Sigma lens, a different lens will have the focal plane somewhere else so that needs to be adjusted.
If you could take a picture of your lens with a ruler so I could figure out how to modify the design I will look into it.

comments.author: CaptainObvious

comments.text:
Hmmm, correct me if I am wrong, but it seems that the only fixed part in the lens is where it says AE14mm etc, etc... right?
That's not good =/, the area is too small for a good grip without affecting the focus and aperture rings, also the camera flash overlaps the place where the clamping ring would be, so it would get on the way of the mechanism.
I'm sorry, I don't think the design can be adapted to your lens, it would have to be one that holds the camera by the tripod mount at the bottom.
Having said that I think it may be possible to make an adapter for that, but I'll have to come up with some way to make it adjustable so that it can work with different distances between the bottom of the camera and the lens axis...
comments.author: Mikesn

comments.text: You are totally right ;)
comments.author: CaptainObvious

comments.text:
Mike, I took a look at the CAD files and... it wasn't pretty. =P
This was one of my first projects in CAD and things are very messy, not easy to make the changes. However the main problem is that I reviewed the photos you took and from what I can tell that lens only has an 7 to 8mm wide area to clamp it, compared with the almost 20mm of the Sigma lens, I'm not confident that narrow clamp would be strong and rigid enough to hold the camera securely.
On the positive side it seems that the focal plane distance is the same in both lenses, so that means I would have to only redesign the lens clamp, I will work on it on the weekend.

I think it would work with the normal PanBaseB, but just in case....

title: thUndead Mini Quadcopter FPV Racer v1

description.text:
Introducing the thUndead mini FPV Racer Quad
Basic Specs:
Frame Diameter: 250mm
All up weight (see components list): 560 g
Features:
  • Lightweight!! (560g AUW in my current setup)
  • 10 degree inclined motors for stupid speed and better FPV
  • Adjustable FPV camera holder to 0 - 90 degrees
  • Vibration damped upper level for FC & gear
  • Vibration damped lower level for your camera (Mobius etc.)
  • plenty of room for gear

My current setup:
  • Dys 1806 2300kv motors
  • 12A ESCs
  • 1300mAh 3S or 4S Turnigy Nano Techs
  • 5x3" three bladed props
  • Quanton FC running Taulabs
  • Mini power distro board with built in 12V reg.
  • TS5823 5.8ghz Vtx
  • Sony 600TLV PCB FPV cam
  • Hobbyking E-OSD
  • Mobius Camera
    Print material: PLA 1.75mm
    Base plates + arms = 70% infill
    Everything else = 35% infill
    To Do list:
  • Come up with a better way of mounting battery (currently velcro which holds pretty good)
    Credits:
  • Arm basic shape inspired by the Hammer Quad arms.

title: Nexus 5 car holder dock with QI charger recess
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
See updated design here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1052861 This is a wireless charging car dock for an LG Google Nexus 5.
Print time: 4 Hrs
Cleanup: 10minutes
Assembly: 10minutes
The phone is inserted from the front, ideal if you are limited on space i.e. between the A-Pillar and stearing wheel.
The holder is designed to fit on industry standard suction bases on most car holders that have a snap fit 4 claw grip between the base and the actual holder (3 out of 3 bases I tried fitted perfectly). It has a recess to take a Qi Charging module (any 70mm dia x 10mm thick QI base will work) see link above. Use 5mm self adhesive felt pads on each claw to prevent scratching your phone. If you are using a case with your phone, you will only require a pad on the side claw.

Print in one piece with the large flat side against your print bed.
There are some small chamfered overhangs in this print but no major bridging.
The snap fits worked perfect on my printer. But snap fits are pretty high tollerance. You may need to adjust your post processing or adjust to fit.
You will also need:
Suction base off a generic car holder with 4 claw type conenction.
See photos attached.
I used my old holder and couldn't find a link to it. This looks identicle to another base i tried successfully and is the cheapest option I found on amazon. Please feedback if this is suitable.
http://www.amazon.co.uk/Mobile-Holder-Universal-Suction-Flexible/dp/B003VBWK3U/
3x felt pads or similar padding
http://www.amazon.co.uk/Divesta-Furniture-Protector-Square-Scratch/dp/B009YUZNYU/ QI charging base (70mm dia, 10mm thick) I used a QUMOX branded charger.
https://www.amazon.co.uk/dp/B00KA7INC0/
It is designed to fit on the industry standard suction bases on most car holders that have a snap fit 4 claw grip between the base and the actual holder (3 out of 3 bases I tried fitted perfectly). It has a recess to take a Qi Charging module (any 70mm dia x 10mm thick QI base will work) see link above. Use 5mm thick self adhesive felt pads on each claw to prevent scratching your phone. If you are using a case with your phone, you will only require a pad on the side claw.
Insert phone corners firts then press back into the side claw.

title: Space Saving Bottle Holder For Fridge

description.text:
The wine bottle holder will hold up your wine on the bottom of a shelf to keep it from rolling around, this is great because it will allow you to store other food on the bottom of your shelf and this wine bottle holder can be used for other types of bottle as well
Sadly I do not have a 3D printer so cannot print this currently but the dimensions are all correct for my own fridge
I have attached an additional picture which shows you where the wine bottle holder is attached ( underneath the shelf that the apple is on or on the shelf above the apple)
Please note 2 of these wine bottle holders will need to be printed to hold 1 bottle of wine
This is actually one of my designs for the #IceboxChallenge checkout my entry here: https://firstbuild.com/rikesh/wine-bottle-holder/
Thanks

author: rikesh942010

description.text:
Simple Solidworks 2014 model that you can Adjust the inside Volume and Wall thicknesses.
Check out this Video for more info:
http://youtu.be/jgnN0x6gR8U
*If you need and special size case and you do not have solidworks, please add a comment of the size of box you need and what it will be used for.***

1)Adjust size of box in solidworks
2) Export file to STL
3) Print File
4) thread 1.75mm filament for hinge, leave 10mm excess on both sides
5) Use a heat gun or lighter to heat up filament
6) Press filament with a knife to the side of the box to fuse together
7) Upload you design for other people to use ;-)

author: Piman5

description.text:
Version 2 of my Mobius camera anti-vibration mount. Find version 1 here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:538604
The main improvements with respect to the previous version are that the design is more precise, thanks to my design skills getting better, and a couple of holes for a zip tie or rapstrap were added in a position that will leave the 3 buttons of the camera entirely accessible.
4 holes are positioned so as to allow mount to a DJIF450, in one of the protruding extensions of the lower frame plate of the quad.
Lateral grooves allow for a quick way to tie the mount to a multirotor with a battery velcro strap. You want one but don't have a 3D printer? No problem! Ask me to print one for you through 3DHubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/rome/hubs/my3d

description.text:
I noticed that the bed would shake and I figure that's really not good for prints. I "field tested" this a LOT to make sure I didn't loose any z height. It rolls along the frame perfectly. There are only 2 parts you need to buy which I've linked. I tried to design this with as little fabrication as possible. All you need is a hack saw and mayme some sand paper to smooth the edges of the rods.
http://www.homedepot.com/p/Unbranded-1-4-in-x-36-in-Plain-Steel-Cold-Rolled-Square-Rod-801197/204273977
http://www.amazon.com/VXB-Skateboard-Bearings-Double-Shielded/dp/B002BBGTK6/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1416070512&sr=8-5&keywords=skateboard+bearings
Video of it in action
http://vid5.photobucket.com/albums/y180/Masurrao/3d%20Printing/20141115%20181406.mp4

I designed windows into the sides so you can see if the rods are inserted all the way.  Cut them to 142 mm exactly and it should be slightly snug inside the frame of the printer.  It wedges onto the end of the aluminum bed.

comments.text: FYI..... that's your z axis
comments.author: jlipavsky79

comments.text: FYI ...... up and down is z axis, left to right is y.  It's stopping it from shaking left to right when printing.
comments.author: jlipavsky79

comments.text: Your stabilizing your z axis from lateral movement, your not stabilizing your y.... it attached to the bed not the print carriage
comments.author: Asylum_Designs

comments.text: When the bed shakes, It's shaking left to right, along the y axis, lateral movement yes.  I know its attached to the bed, I made the thing.  Your y axis isn't just the hardware that moves the carriage left to right, its any movement in those directions.
comments.author: jlipavsky79

comments.text: Z-WOBBLE please look it up....Z not y, I'm going to guess your new to this...
comments.author: Asylum_Designs

comments.text: Trolls gonna troll I guess.  Not new, have you ever hear of the Cartesian Coordinate system?   You know, x-axis y axis and z axis?   The movement of the Z-WOBBLE your so fond of capitalizing is in the y axis direction, not the z axis and not the x axis. HENCE why its called a y stabilizer.   Are you trolling every person who made something to fix this and called it something you don't like?
comments.author: jlipavsky79

comments.text: 5 years of printing has taught me that not all movements are refered to in their axis oriented movement, some thing are slop and slop in one axis doesn't take the name from a different one, if you had verticle slop in your x axis would you call that z stabilizing or would you be stabilizing your x.....slop is not a intentional movement nor does it have a axis discription  other than the attached axis, it's not that I don't like it, it's that your wrong, this community is based one teaching each other so the cause moves forward.... take a lesson, I've been cnc machining for 15 years, these descriptions have been used for decades, it's not me telling you your wrong, it when community of people over the decade that have refined this art, please rethink your perception of of what I'm saying as helpful instead of harmful, learn from the people that have been doing this for over a decade, this isn't new tech, it's old tech with a new material, the gcode your printer runs on has been the same for over 20 years now, embrace people trying to help, don't tell them they are a fool...not very maker like......
comments.author: Asylum_Designs

comments.text: Ok fair enough, and I apologise for snapping, but you need to realise the way you come off is very condescending.  Starting off with just an "fyi, your wrong" and continuing with all caps replies and basically assuming I was a fool , exactly what you're accusing me of doing to you, is not the best way to teach your lessons.  Instead of expecting people to assume you're the smartest person in the room, maybe next time start off with "Hey I realize what you're trying to fix, but I work in the industry and what you're working on is actually referred to as a, b, and c."  It's a much nicer way to communicate your ideas when no one knows who you are or what your history is.
comments.author: jlipavsky79

comments.text: And I am sorry for coming off like that, I should have worded it differently and for that I'm sorry, I like your idea to stop your lateral movement issue, I see that problem a lot across all of the machines, I do have an idea to make it better. I sketched something up but don't know how to add a picture to this comment...

comments.text: I originally thought of using springs for ease of install but thought it would affect the rigidity of the build platform.  I wanted it to be as rigid as possible.  Not a professional engineer though and I usually go by the motto of "overkill is underrated" so if you got strong enough springs it might keep it more than stable for the vibrations that the printhead creates.
